The slide is titled "Main findings" and is labeled as RQ1. It shows a graph with different validation methods on weak labels. There are three categories of validation methods: "Validation on Weak Labels" in orange, "No Validation, Random Selection" in purple, and "Validation on Clean Labels" in green. The x-axis represents different methods: FT_w, BOND, COSINE, MLC, and L2R. The y-axis shows the relative performance improvement over weak labels in percentage. The graph indicates that "Validation on Clean Labels" generally shows the highest improvement, while "No Validation, Random Selection" shows the lowest improvement.

How do LLMs perform on Constrained Language Planning? Dataset: wikiHow + Generated ConstraintsConstraint Type 1: Modifier Definition: A word, an adjective or a phrase that modifies or constrains an abstract goal. Ex.1: Make a chocolate cake. Ex.2: Make a pink cake.Constraint Type 2: Method Definition: A tool or specified mode that controls the process for achieving the goal. Ex.1: Make a cake with an oven. Ex.2: Make a cake by using cake mix.Constraint Type 3: Intent Definition: An additional purpose or demand when completing the goal. Ex.1: Make a cake for wedding. Ex.2: Make a cake for diabetics.

The content is about a method for generating specific goals from an abstract goal. It starts with an input of an abstract goal, like "Make a cake." Then, it uses InstructGPT for in-context learning to generate specific goals. There are three specific goals shown: G1 is to make a chocolate cake, G2 is to make a cake in a microwave, and G3 is to make a cake for a wedding.

The content is: "Method. Input: an abstract goal. Step 1: Generate specific goals with InstructGPT via in-context learning. Abstract Goal: Make a cake. Specific Goals: G1, modifier, Make a chocolate cake. G2, method, Make a cake in a microwave. G3, intent, Make a cake for a wedding. Step 2: Over-generate candidate scripts with InstructGPT via in-context learning. Candidate Scripts: 1, 2, 3, ... k."

The image shows a slide titled "Method". It explains a process for achieving an abstract goal of making a cake. The first step is to input an abstract goal and generate specific goals using InstructGPT via in - context learning. The second step is to over - generate candidate scripts with InstructGPT via in - context learning. The abstract goal is "Make a cake". Specific goals include "Make a chocolate cake", "Make a cake in a microwave", and "Make a cake for a wedding". There are candidate scripts numbered 1 to k for the specific goal "Make a chocolate cake".

Method. Step 2: Over - generate candidate scripts with InstructGPT via in - context learning. Step 3: Find filtered scripts to the goal with InstructGPT via similarity score. Output: Specific goals with corresponding scripts.

Step 1: Generate specific goals with InstructGPT via in-context learning. Step 2: Over-generate candidate scripts with InstructGPT via in-context learning. Step 3: Find filtered scripts to the goal with InstructGPT via similarity score. Output: Specific goals with corresponding plans.

Constraint Analysis shows high heterogeneity and pluralism in the generated specific goals. Coscript for Smaller Language Models. Datasets: Coscript, wikiHow. Metrics: Faithful: DeBERTa, v3 large, model to decide whether the generated texts are faithful to the constraints. Automatic metrics: ROUGE, BLEU, BERTScore.
Specialized Models vs. LLMs. Smaller LMs fine - tuned on Coscript can generate higher quality scripts than LLMs.

Summary and Takeaways.- Establish the constrained language planning problem.- Evaluate constrained language planning ability of LLMs and develop an over - generate - then - filter method for LLMs.- Use LLMs to generate a high - quality script dataset, CoScript, for constrained language planning.- Limitations and future work.- The proposed method for improving LLMs is a post - hoc re - ranking approach.- CoScript only inherits from an abstract one with one extra constraint.- CoScript dataset can be a valuable resource to advance the research on language planning with more complex and diverse goals and constraints.

Comparison of pre - training strategies, data sources and sizes. PubMedBERT, BioBERT, ClinicalBERT and other.III. Evaluation of 13 models on 11 tasks. DrBERT achieves state - of - the - art results in 9 downstream French medical - oriented tasks. It surpasses CamemBERT generic model and English - based domain - specific models. It also confirms the utility of training a medical - specific model in French.Data sources matter. Training on heterogeneous data is important. NACHOS is more robust than using private clinical data only. More data is better, but does not scale well. Continual pretraining is a more effective strategy when based on domain - specific English models. The DrBERT models, the NACHOS dataset and the training scripts are freely available under the MIT license.

Attention as a Guide for Simultaneous Speech Translation Sara Papi, Matteo Negri, Marco Turchi
Simultaneous speech translation, SimulST, is the process of translating spoken language into a text in another language in real - time, enabling cross - language communication.
Specific architectures are usually trained, introducing additional modules to be optimized.

The problems of the current SimulST models are: Specific architectures are usually trained, introducing additional modules to be optimized. Long and complicated training procedures, for example, different optimization objectives.

The problems of the current SimulST models are:.- Specific architectures are usually trained, introducing additional modules to be optimized.- Long and complicated training procedures, for example, different optimization objectives.- Training and maintaining several models to reach different latency regimes, like 1s, 2s, and so on.
What is our solution?

What is our solution? Use already existing offline ST models without re - training or adopting specific architecture for SimulST. Use only one model for every latency regime and handle latency through specific parameters.

What is our solution? Use already existing offline ST models without re - training or adopting specific architecture for SimulST. Use only one model for every latency regime and handle latency through specific parameters. Leverage the knowledge already acquired by the model through the attention mechanism between audio input and textual output.

Why do matched prefixes affect LM judgements?We perturb context sentences in ways that preserve the relevant structure, and ask whether models are similarly sensitive to these sentences.- Prefix/suffix adverbs: "However, <sent>.". - Long prefix adverbs: "First and foremost, <sent>.". - Add clause: "Regardless of what X thinks about it, <sent>.". - Quote: "Yesterday, X said, <sent>.".

Key Takeaways Language models are sensitive to latent syntactic/semantic features shared across sentences. MPP evaluations with short, single-sentence inputs do not fully capture LMs' abstract knowledge.

Well, there are a few common ones. One is comparative evaluation, where you compare different dialogue systems. Another is Likert rating evaluation, which uses a scale for rating. There's also human evaluation, where humans assess the dialogue systems. And then there's automated evaluation, which uses algorithms to analyze the dialogue. So, those are some of the main methods. XSemPLR.We provide a unified dataset XSemPLR for cross-lingual semantic parsing in multiple natural languages and meaning representations. It contains:.- 9 datasets in various domains.- 5 semantic parsing tasks.- 8 meaning representations.- 22 natural languages in 15 language families.

Other Results & Findings, Section 4 in Paper, Enc-Dec, mT5, outperforms previous work or achieves comparable results. Pretraining on the English NL can significantly boost the performance of few-shot on target NLs. Multilingual LLMs, Codex & BLOOM, are still inadequate for crosslingual semantic parsing tasks. Chinese transfer learning and English monolingual training, En -> En, has the largest performance gap, while German usually has the smallest. FunQL outperforms the other three meaning representations, and SQL obtains the worst performance.

Conclusion.- We build XSemPLR, a unified benchmark for cross-lingual semantic parsing with multiple natural languages and meaning representations.- We conduct a comprehensive benchmark study on three representative types of multilingual language models.- Our results show that mT5 with monolingual training yields the best performance, while notably multilingual LLMs are still inadequate to perform cross-lingual semantic parsing tasks. Moreover, the performance gap between monolingual training and cross-lingual transfer learning is still significant.

Conclusion.- We build XSemPLR, a unified benchmark for cross-lingual semantic parsing with multiple natural languages and meaning representations.- We conduct a comprehensive benchmark study on three representative types of multilingual language models.- Our results show that mT5 with monolingual training yields the best performance, while notably multilingual LLMs are still inadequate to perform cross-lingual semantic parsing tasks. Pandan Cake, Pandan cake is a light, fluffy, green - coloured sponge cake flavoured with the juices of Pandanus amaryllifolius leaves. Question: Do datasets and models have positionality? Goal: Compare annotations from users with existing datasets and models.
NLPositionality A framework for characterizing design biases in NLP datasets and models

Collection: 300 instances are sampled from a dataset. Each instance has an associated gold label. Processing: Instances are sent as part of a study on LITW. Annotations from people around the world. The received annotations are compared against the gold labels from the dataset and predictions obtained from the models. Analysis: Pearson's r correlation is measured between gold labels, model predictions and annotations for each of the demographics separately.

So, what can we do? Addressing positionality in NLP

1. Keep a record of all relevant design choices made throughout building datasets or models. 2. Do NLP research through the lens of perspectivism:. a. Share disaggregated dataset labels! b. Use modeling techniques that can handle annotator disagreement.

Recommendations. 1. Keep a record of all relevant design choices made throughout building datasets or models. 2. Do NLP research through the lens of perspectivism: a. Share disaggregated dataset labels! b. Use modeling techniques that can handle annotator disagreement. 3. Building specialized datasets and models with and for specific communities is valuable for inclusive NLP, e.g., Masakhane initiative.

Well, you see, permuting the tokens for the output sequence is necessary because it helps in generating a more diverse and accurate output. It allows the model to explore different possible arrangements of the tokens, which can lead to better understanding and representation of the data. This is especially important in tasks like machine translation or text generation where the order of words matters a great deal. So, it's all about improving the quality and versatility of the output. If you have any more questions about this or anything else, feel free to ask!

Well, it's because transparency about bias mitigation methods helps in understanding how the model is being made fair. It allows others to see the steps taken to reduce bias, which is really important for building trust. And it also helps in improving the model further. So, yeah, that's why they recommended it. Well, the findings suggest that the smaller T5 model, when fine - tuned on Coscript, can generate higher quality scripts than larger LLMs. This implies that for certain tasks, like script generation, smaller models can be more effective if they are properly trained on the right data. It also shows that there might be a lot of potential in using specialized data for training models. So, it could be a good direction for future research and development in this area. Multi-modal Instruction Tuning

Multi-Modal Instruction Turning.Training Dataset Construction:.- Use 53 tasks from 9 groups for training.- Sample 10, 000 instances per task.Testing Dataset Construction:.- Reserve the entire Commonsense Reasoning group for testing.- Select additional 5 tasks from VQA and Miscellaneous groups.- We use all the instances in the test split for each task.- Randomly sample 20 tasks from the test split of Natural Instructions dataset as unseen tasks for NLP.

Multi-Modal Instruction Turning.Training Dataset Construction:.- Use 53 tasks from 9 groups for training.- Sample 10, 000 instances per task.Testing Dataset Construction:.- Reserve the entire Commonsense Reasoning group for testing.- Select additional 5 tasks from VQA and Miscellaneous groups.- We use all the instances in the test split for each task.- Randomly sample 20 tasks from the test split of Natural Instructions dataset as unseen tasks for NLP.

Implementation Details.Training details:.- Pre-trained OFA-Large model, 472M,.- Mix all the instances for all tasks.- Each instance is randomly combined with one of its five instruction templates.Testing details:.- For each task, we conduct a total of five experiments by evaluating the model using one of the five instructions in each experiment.- We report the mean and maximum performance and the standard deviation of the performance across all five experiments.

Implementation Details.Training details:.- Pre-trained OFA-Large model, 472M,.- Mix all the instances for all tasks.- Each instance is randomly combined with one of its five instruction templates.Testing details:.- For each task, we conduct a total of five experiments by evaluating the model using one of the five instructions in each experiment.- We report the mean and maximum performance and the standard deviation of the performance across all five experiments.

Implementation Details.Training details:.- Pre-trained OFA-Large model, 472M,.- Mix all the instances for all tasks.- Each instance is randomly combined with one of its five instruction templates.Testing details:.- For each task, we conduct a total of five experiments by evaluating the model using one of the five instructions in each experiment.- We report the mean and maximum performance and the standard deviation of the performance across all five experiments.

Evaluation Metrics.For multi-modal classification tasks, Visual Entailment, Visual Spatial Reasoning, Natural Language Visual Reasoning, and Disaster Type Classification, we report the Accuracy.For multi-modal generation tasks, Commonsense VQA, Text VQA, Grounded VQA, Visual Text Extraction, and Visual Dialogue, we report the Rouge-L.For NLP tasks, we report Rouge-L.We also compute the aggregated performance for each model based on the mean of the model's performance on all multimodal and NLP unseen tasks. We use Rouge-L as the performance score for most tasks, and Accuracy for tasks that only have accuracy as a metric.

Conclusion.First large-scale multi-modal instruction tuning dataset.Contains 62 multi-modal tasks from 10 broad categories.Significantly improve the zero-shot capability of OFA via instruction tuning.Explore several transferring learning techniques and show their benefits.Design a new metric sensitivity.
One More Thing! We are collecting a much larger multimodal instruction tuning dataset with around 150 additional vision-language tasks and we will release them soon!
